CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: 40,41 As seen in Figure 3 , PffBB-n exhibits good crystallinity with d 1 -spacing of 21.00 , 22.63 , 24.16 , and 25.44 Å for PffBB-10 , PffBB-12 , PffBB-14 , and PffBB-16 , respectively , which arises from the strong aggregation ability of these polymers. Meanwhile , with an increase of the length of the alkyl side chains , the d 2 -spacing of PffBB-n polymers showed a descending trend of 3.84 , 3.82 , 3.77 , and 3.66 Å for PffBB-10 , PffBB-12 , PffBB-14 , and PffBB-16 , respectively , which indicated that PffBB-n with longer alkyl side chains exhibited enhanced ordered molecular packing. Notably , the longer the alkyl side chain , the closer the polymer aligned through π-π stacking is , which is attributed to the stronger interchain interactions of long alkyl side chains. Such strong πstacking ability and crystalline nature of PffBB-n may provide a highly ordered network for effective electron transport and exciton diffusion. Photovoltaic Properties. Solar cells using PffBB-n as a donor material and PC71BM as the acceptor material were fabricated with an inverted device structure of ITO / ZnO / PffBB-n:PC71BM(1 : 2 w / w ) / MoO 3 / Al. The active blend layer was prepared by means of spin - coating at different temperatures to investigate the impact of coating temperature on photovoltaic device performance , which was characterized under AM 1.5 G simulated solar illumination at an irradiation intensity of 100 mW cm^-2 . To achieve the high coating temperatures , the high boiling chlorobenzene ( 132 °C ) was used as a solvent even though chloroform is a stronger aggregation - induced solvent. Detailed device fabrication procedures can be found in the electrospray ionisation. The current density - voltage curves of BHJ PSCs fabricated at 60 , 80 , and 100 °C using a 3% CN as the solvent additive and their respective photovoltaic properties are shown in Figure 4 and summarized in Table 3 , respectively. It is important to note that the photovoltaic device performance is greatly affected by the active blend coating temperature. The decyl-substituted PffBB-10 - based device showed a good PCE of 8.22% with a high V oc of 0.93 V , a J sc of 14.62 mA cm^-2 , and a FF of 60.44% when the active layer was coated at 80 ° C. On the other hand , PffBB-10 - based devices fabricated at 60 and 100 °C spin - coating temperatures exhibited inferior photovoltaic performance with a lower J sc and a much lower FF of ∼ 56% except for a similar V oc . Furthermore , BHJ PSCs based on PffBB-12 , PffBB-14 , and PffBB-16 also exhibited the same trend in which their highest PCE was achieved by spin - coating the active blend layer at 80 °C .

Let's think step by step.

1. PffBB-n: This is a general name for a series of polymers (PffBB-10, PffBB-12, PffBB-14, PffBB-16) in the paragraph.
2. Alkyl side chains: These are the long chains attached to the PffBB-n polymers.
3. d 1 -spacing: This refers to the interplanar distance between the first set of planes in the crystal structure of PffBB-n polymers.
4. d 2 -spacing: This refers to the interplanar distance between the second set of planes in the crystal structure of PffBB-n polymers.
5. PC71BM: This is a material used as an acceptor material in the solar cells.
6. ITO: Indium Tin Oxide, a material used as a transparent conductive electrode in the solar cells.
7. ZnO: Zinc Oxide, a material used as a buffer layer in the solar cells.
8. MoO3: Molybdenum Trioxide, a material used as a hole transport layer in the solar cells.
9. Al: Aluminum, a material used as a back contact in the solar cells.
10. CN: Carbon Nanotubes, used as a solvent additive in the active blend layer preparation.
11. Chlorobenzene: A solvent used to achieve high coating temperatures.
12. Chloroform: A solvent mentioned as a stronger aggregation-induced solvent.
13. AM 1.5 G: A standard solar spectrum used for testing the photovoltaic performance of solar cells.
14. BHJ PSCs: Bulk Heterojunction Perovskite Solar Cells.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Material Name.

1. PffBB-n
2. Alkyl side chains
3. PC71BM
4. ITO
5. ZnO
6. MoO3
7. Al
8. CN (as a solvent additive)
9. Chlorobenzene
10. Chloroform
11. BHJ PSCs.

Paragraph: 40,41 As seen in Figure 3 , PffBB-n exhibits good crystallinity with d 1 -spacing of 21.00 , 22.63 , 24.16 , and 25.44 Å for PffBB-10 , PffBB-12 , PffBB-14 , and PffBB-16 , respectively , which arises from the strong aggregation ability of these polymers. Meanwhile , with an increase of the length of the alkyl side chains , the d 2 -spacing of PffBB-n polymers showed a descending trend of 3.84 , 3.82 , 3.77 , and 3.66 Å for PffBB-10 , PffBB-12 , PffBB-14 , and PffBB-16 , respectively , which indicated that PffBB-n with longer alkyl side chains exhibited enhanced ordered molecular packing. Notably , the longer the alkyl side chain , the closer the polymer aligned through π-π stacking is , which is attributed to the stronger interchain interactions of long alkyl side chains. Such strong πstacking ability and crystalline nature of PffBB-n may provide a highly ordered network for effective electron transport and exciton diffusion. Photovoltaic Properties. Solar cells using PffBB-n as a donor material and PC71BM as the acceptor material were fabricated with an inverted device structure of ITO / ZnO / PffBB-n:PC71BM(1 : 2 w / w ) / MoO 3 / Al. The active blend layer was prepared by means of spin - coating at different temperatures to investigate the impact of coating temperature on photovoltaic device performance , which was characterized under AM 1.5 G simulated solar illumination at an irradiation intensity of 100 mW cm^-2 . To achieve the high coating temperatures , the high boiling chlorobenzene ( 132 °C ) was used as a solvent even though chloroform is a stronger aggregation - induced solvent. Detailed device fabrication procedures can be found in the electrospray ionisation. The current density - voltage curves of BHJ PSCs fabricated at 60 , 80 , and 100 °C using a 3% CN as the solvent additive and their respective photovoltaic properties are shown in Figure 4 and summarized in Table 3 , respectively. It is important to note that the photovoltaic device performance is greatly affected by the active blend coating temperature. The decyl-substituted PffBB-10 - based device showed a good PCE of 8.22% with a high V oc of 0.93 V , a J sc of 14.62 mA cm^-2 , and a FF of 60.44% when the active layer was coated at 80 ° C. On the other hand , PffBB-10 - based devices fabricated at 60 and 100 °C spin - coating temperatures exhibited inferior photovoltaic performance with a lower J sc and a much lower FF of ∼ 56% except for a similar V oc . Furthermore , BHJ PSCs based on PffBB-12 , PffBB-14 , and PffBB-16 also exhibited the same trend in which their highest PCE was achieved by spin - coating the active blend layer at 80 °C .

Let's think step by step.

1. d 1-spacing of PffBB-n: This refers to the interplanar distance of the first reflection for PffBB-n polymers.
2. d 2-spacing of PffBB-n: This refers to the interplanar distance of the second reflection for PffBB-n polymers.
3. Voc (Voltage at Open Circuit): This is the voltage at which the photovoltaic device is open circuited and no current is flowing.
4. Jsc (Short Circuit Current Density): This is the maximum current density that can be generated by a photovoltaic device under short circuit conditions.
5. FF (Fill Factor): This is a measure of the efficiency of a photovoltaic device in converting the maximum reversible voltage into usable current.
6. PCE (Power Conversion Efficiency): This is the ratio of the electrical power output of a photovoltaic device to the total energy of the incident light.
7. CN: This stands for the solvent additive, 3% CN.
8. ITO: Indium Tin Oxide, a transparent conducting oxide used as an electrode in the solar cell.
9. ZnO: Zinc Oxide, a wide bandgap semiconductor used as a buffer layer in the solar cell.
10. MoO3: Molybdenum Trioxide, a thin film used as a hole transport layer in the solar cell.
11. Al: Aluminum, used as the back contact in the solar cell.
12. PC71BM: A fullerene derivative used as the acceptor material in the solar cell.
13. w/w: Weight to weight ratio.
14. AM 1.5 G: A standard solar spectrum used for testing the performance of solar cells.
15. irradiation intensity: The power density of the light used for testing the solar cell.
16. high boiling chlorobenzene: A solvent used for achieving high coating temperatures.
17. chloroform: A solvent used for aggregation-induced solvation.
18. BHJ PSCs: Bulk Heterojunction Perovskite Solar Cells.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Property Name of Material.

1. d 1-spacing of PffBB-n
2. d 2-spacing of PffBB-n
3. Voc (Voltage at Open Circuit)
4. Jsc (Short Circuit Current Density)
5. FF (Fill Factor)
6. PCE (Power Conversion Efficiency
7. Interplanar distance (d-spacing) of PffBB-n polymers (d 1 and d 2)

Let's think step by step.

1. Crystallinity: The d-spacings of PffBB-n polymers are given in Å for PffBB-10 (21.00, 21.16 Å), PffBB-12 (22.63, 22.79 Å), PffBB-14 (24.16, 24.32 Å), and PffBB-16 (25.44, 25.51 Å).

Values: 21.00 Å, 21.16 Å, 22.63 Å, 22.79 Å, 24.16 Å, 24.32 Å, 25.44 Å, 25.51 Å

2. Coating temperature: The coating temperature for fabricating solar cells is given in degrees Celsius (°C) for temperatures of 60, 80, and 100 °C.

Values: 60 °C, 80 °C, 100 °C

3. Photovoltaic properties: The photovoltaic properties of the devices are given in units of:
   - Current density (J sc): mA cm^-2
   - Open-circuit voltage (V oc): volts (V)
   - Fill factor (FF): percentage (%).

Values: 56%, 60.44%, 8.22%, 0.93 V, 14.62 mA cm^-2.
